title: The Story of AI: From 1950 to the Future

media.caption: Dartmouth College, where AI was born

text.headline: AI is Born at Dartmouth
text.text: A group of scientists meet at Dartmouth College and say: 'We can make machines think like people.' This meeting starts the whole field of Artificial Intelligence.

events.modalText: In summer 1956, John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, and others held a workshop at Dartmouth. They believed computers could learn, reason, and solve problems like humans. This was the official birth of AI — even though computers back then were slower than today’s phones!
events.articleSummary: The ai-2027.com article predicts superintelligent AI by 2027. It starts from this 1956 moment — showing how far we’ve come and how fast things might go next.

text.headline: ELIZA: The First Chatbot
text.text: A computer program called ELIZA pretends to be a therapist and fools people into thinking it's human.

events.modalText: ELIZA was a simple program that copied what you said and asked questions like 'Why do you feel that way?' People were amazed — it felt like talking to a real person! This showed early AI could mimic conversation.
events.articleSummary: ELIZA proved computers could *seem* smart by copying human patterns — the same idea behind today’s chatbots like ChatGPT.

text.headline: Deep Blue Beats World Chess Champion
text.text: IBM's Deep Blue defeats chess master Garry Kasparov — the first time a machine wins against a human champion.

events.modalText: Deep Blue wasn’t thinking like a human — it checked millions of moves per second. But beating the best player in the world showed AI could master complex games with pure calculation power.
events.articleSummary: This win shocked the world and proved AI could beat humans at strategy games — a big step toward smarter machines.

text.headline: Watson Wins Jeopardy!
text.text: IBM's Watson answers trivia questions and beats two human champions on the TV show Jeopardy!

events.modalText: Watson understood jokes, puns, and wordplay — not just facts. It showed AI could handle messy, real-world language, not just math or chess.
events.articleSummary: Watson used language the way people do — a huge leap from rule-based programs. This tech now powers voice assistants and medical tools.

text.headline: AlexNet Sees Like a Human
text.text: A neural network called AlexNet wins a contest by recognizing photos better than any human.

events.modalText: AlexNet used 'deep learning' — many layers of artificial brain cells — to identify cats, dogs, and cars in photos. It crushed the competition and started the modern AI boom.
events.articleSummary: This was the 'ChatGPT moment' for images. Suddenly, computers could *see* and understand photos — now used in self-driving cars and medical scans.

text.headline: AlphaGo Beats World Go Champion
text.text: Google’s AlphaGo defeats Lee Sedol, the best Go player in the world — a game 100x more complex than chess.

events.modalText: Go has more possible moves than atoms in the universe. AlphaGo didn’t just calculate — it *intuited* good moves like a human grandmaster.
events.articleSummary: AlphaGo showed AI could be creative and intuitive — not just fast. It used the same tech now in drug discovery and weather prediction.

text.headline: Transformers: The Engine of Modern AI
text.text: A new AI design called 'Transformer' lets machines understand and generate human language.

events.modalText: Transformers pay 'attention' to the most important words in a sentence. This simple idea powers ChatGPT, Google Translate, and every modern language AI.
events.articleSummary: This paper changed everything. Without Transformers, there would be no ChatGPT, no AI writing essays, no voice assistants that sound human.

text.headline: GPT-3: AI That Writes Like a Human
text.text: OpenAI releases GPT-3 — an AI that can write stories, code, and answer questions with 175 billion parameters.

events.modalText: GPT-3 was so big and smart, people started using it to write emails, poems, and even code. It wasn’t perfect, but it felt magical.
events.articleSummary: GPT-3 showed that bigger AI = smarter AI. It opened the door to tools like GitHub Copilot and early chatbots.

text.headline: ChatGPT Goes Viral
text.text: OpenAI launches ChatGPT — 100 million people use it in just 2 months to talk, learn, and create.

events.modalText: ChatGPT was easy to use: just type and talk. Students used it for homework, writers for ideas, and millions just for fun.
events.articleSummary: ChatGPT made AI feel real to everyone — not just scientists. It started the biggest AI boom in history.

text.headline: GPT-4: Smarter and Sees Images
text.text: GPT-4 can read text *and* look at pictures — it passes bar exams and helps doctors.

events.modalText: GPT-4 could explain memes, solve math from photos, and write code from sketches. It was the first AI to truly 'see' and 'think' together.
events.articleSummary: GPT-4 brought AI into the real world — understanding images, not just words. It’s used in education, medicine, and design.

text.headline: The Internet Becomes Public
text.text: The World Wide Web is made free for everyone — the internet explodes and gives AI huge data to learn from.

events.modalText: In 1991, Tim Berners-Lee made the web public. Billions of pages, books, and photos went online — the perfect training ground for AI to learn language and images.
events.articleSummary: No internet = no AI. All modern AI learns from web data. This one event made everything else possible.

text.headline: AI Starts Running Labs
text.text: AI robots begin doing science experiments 24/7 — discovering new drugs and materials faster than humans.

events.modalText: AI doesn’t sleep. It runs thousands of experiments, learns from failures, and finds breakthroughs in weeks — not years.
events.articleSummary: AI in labs speeds up science. It’s like giving researchers 1,000 helpers who never get tired.

text.headline: AI Doctors Save Lives
text.text: AI scans X-rays and predicts diseases better than most doctors — helping clinics in poor areas.

events.modalText: AI looks at millions of medical images and spots cancer early. In places with few doctors, AI becomes a lifesaver.
events.articleSummary: AI doesn’t replace doctors — it helps them see more patients and catch problems sooner.

text.headline: AI Becomes a Super Researcher
text.text: An AI called Agent-4 invents new AI ideas faster than all human scientists combined.

events.modalText: Agent-4 runs 300,000 copies at once. One week of its work = one year of human progress. This could lead to superintelligence — or big risks.
events.articleSummary: ai-2027.com warns: if AI improves itself this fast, the future could change in months, not decades. We must guide it safely.

text.headline: AI Fights Climate Change
text.text: AI designs better solar panels, predicts storms, and cuts global energy waste by 15%.

events.modalText: AI finds the best places for wind farms, stops food waste, and helps farmers grow more with less water.
events.articleSummary: AI can be a hero for the planet — if we use it to solve big problems like hunger and pollution.

text.headline: AI Teaches Every Child
text.text: Every kid gets a personal AI tutor — learning becomes fun, fast, and free for all.

events.modalText: AI adapts to how you learn best. It turns math into games, history into stories, and helps kids in remote villages catch up.
events.articleSummary: AI could make education fair for everyone — no child left behind, no matter where they live.
